name: Valve-Sparing Root Replacement in Marfan Syndrome
description: Valve-sparing root replacement (VSRR) preserves the native aortic valve while replacing the aortic root, eliminating the need for lifelong anticoagulation. The David procedure (reimplantation) and Yacoub procedure (remodeling) are the two main techniques. The David procedure is preferred in Marfan syndrome due to annular stabilization. Excellent long-term outcomes in experienced centers make this the preferred approach for suitable young Marfan patients.

david_procedure_reimplantation.description: Aortic valve reimplanted inside a Dacron tube graft with annular stabilization
steps: 1. Excise aortic sinuses leaving 4-5mm rim above annulus
3. Size graft based on cusp height and annular diameter
4. Place annular sutures (horizontal mattress with pledgets)
5. Seat graft over valve and tie sutures
6. Reimplant valve cusps to graft (inside-out sutures)

graft_sizing.formula: Height of cusp + 5-6mm determines graft diameter

david_procedure_reimplantation.annular_stabilization: Annulus is stabilized within the graft, preventing dilation
advantages: Lower reoperation rate than remodeling in Marfan

yacoub_procedure_remodeling.description: Separate grafts tailored to recreate sinuses of Valsalva
yacoub_procedure_remodeling.technique: Scalloped graft sewn to annulus following cusp attachment lines

concern_in_marfan.annular_dilation: No annular stabilization - risk of progressive dilation
concern_in_marfan.recommendation: Generally avoided in Marfan syndrome due to higher late failure

modified_david_techniques.david_v: Graft with neosinuses (Valsalva graft) - improved hemodynamics
modified_david_techniques.variation: Stanford modification with graft sizing algorithms

ideal_candidate: No significant aortic regurgitation from cusp pathology
relative_contraindications: Severe cusp prolapse requiring complex repair
patient_selection.intraoperative_decision: Final determination after direct cusp inspection

cusp_prolapse.assessment: Central coaptation height should be 8-10mm above annulus
cusp_prolapse.free_margin_resuspension: Suture resuspension for more severe prolapse

cusp_assessment_and_repair.effective_height: Distance from annulus to free margin in closed position

reoperation_rate.yacoub_in_marfan: 15-25% at 10 years (higher due to annular dilation)

outcomes.endocarditis: Similar to native valve (lower than prosthetic)

advantages_over_bentall.no_anticoagulation: Major advantage in young, active patients

center_experience.learning_curve: Steep - recommend minimum 20-30 cases/year for Marfan VSRR
center_experience.outcomes: Significantly better at high-volume experienced centers
center_experience.recommendation: Refer to specialized aortic center for optimal results

clinical_pearls: David (reimplantation) > Yacoub (remodeling) in Marfan due to annular stabilization
Cusp effective height >9mm predicts stable long-term result
90%+ freedom from reoperation at 10 years in experienced hands
Avoid VSRR if cusp tissue is poor - Bentall is safer option
learning_objectives: Identify appropriate candidates for valve-sparing root replacement in Marfan syndrome
Describe cusp assessment parameters predicting durable repair
